title: Witch (dNetHack)

| A witch:* can [fly](/wiki/Fly "Fly").
* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").
* is [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivore "Omnivore").
* is not a valid [polymorphable](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") form.
* is a [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)").
* is female.
* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").
* can pick up weapons and food.
* can pick up [magical items](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item").
* can be seen through [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). |                                                                                        |

A **witch**, @, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"). The witch is a [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") woman that is capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight") and [spellcasting](/wiki/DNetHack_monster_spells "DNetHack monster spells"), can be seen via [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and will seek out and collect items, particularly [magical items](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item").

A witch has a single weapon attack, and will attempt to cast spells clerically once during each of her turns: she can cast [psi bolt](/wiki/Psi_bolt "Psi bolt"), [acid rain](/index.php?title=Acid_rain\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Acid rain (page does not exist)"), [evil eye](/index.php?title=Evil_eye_\(monster_spell\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Evil eye (monster spell) (page does not exist)"), and [curse items](/wiki/Curse_items "Curse items") with an equal probability of each. A witch can only cast spells if [her familiar](/wiki/Witch%27s_familiar "Witch's familiar") is present, but is able to do so without any cooldown, and will summon another familiar if hers is killed.

## Generation

Witches are not randomly generated, and are not a valid form for polymorph. An [apprentice witch](/wiki/Apprentice_witch "Apprentice witch") can grow up into a regular witch.

At level creation, three witches are generated accompanying their apprentices and the coven leader in the Temples of the Old Gods within the [Neutral Quest](/wiki/Neutral_Quest_\(dNetHack\) "Neutral Quest (dNetHack)"). A witch's familiar is generated alongside each witch, at the same level as her.

A witch is [always generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") black [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots"), a [plain dress](/wiki/Plain_dress "Plain dress"), a black [cloak](/wiki/Plain_cloak "Plain cloak"), a black [pair of gloves](/wiki/Pair_of_gloves "Pair of gloves"), a [witch hat](/wiki/Witch_hat "Witch hat"), and either a [stiletto](/wiki/Stiletto "Stiletto") (9⁄10 chance) or an [athame](/wiki/Athame "Athame") (1⁄10 chance).

## Strategy

Witches are likely to be quite an annoyance on their own, even without their familiars' [open wounds](/wiki/Open_wounds "Open wounds") spells all but forcing you to avoid line-of-sight when approaching the witch coven. Though a familiar's casting abilities and importance to her witch should make the them a priority target in theory, only the witches are capable of flying - in practice, this results in them leaving the familiars behind to cast at you from across the river. Dealing with the witch battalion generally requires that characters have a high amount of HP and a source of [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Witchcraft](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witchcraft "wikipedia:Witchcraft")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[The Dreams in the Witch House](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Dreams_in_the_Witch_House "wikipedia:The Dreams in the Witch House")***

Witchcraft refers to the alleged use of supernatural or magic powers primarily to inflict harm and misfortune upon others, with practitioners of the art known as "witches". European belief in witchcraft traces back to classical antiquity, with medieval and early modern European cultures playing host to [witch hunting](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witch_hunt "wikipedia:Witch hunt"): the accused "witches" were usually women believed to have used black magic or maleficium against their own community, with the accusations borne of social tensions and believed by some anthropologists to have been focused on supposed enemies of the Church. Witchcraft is also generally considered malevolent in many indigenous belief systems, with people seeking healers and medicine people for protection against witchcraft. Believed to be driven by evil spirits or substances, suspected historical witches were intimidated, banished, attacked or outright killed - often they would be formally prosecuted and punished if they considered or simply believed to be guilty, resulting in tens of thousands of executions.

Witchcraft in its modern context generally refers to followers of certain types of modern paganism, who self-identify as witches and use the term witchcraft for their beliefs and practices, though some other neo-pagans avoid the term due to its negative connotations. Witches are also depicted in various forms of media as practitioners of magic that can range from empowered humans to almighty sorcerers to monstrous hag-like beings, and there are many instances of a witch "species" separate from mundane humanity. Witches in fairy tales and cartoons, particularly of the "monster" variety, are often depicted as long-nosed crones that are malevolent and seen as hideous witch croaky voices and shrieking laughs - they often wear distinct pointed brimmed hats and are sometimes depicted taking flight, with the stereotypical witch using a broom; many of these qualities are sometimes omitted or even subverted in modern depictions.

The witches of *dNetHack* are mostly based on cultists from the [Cthulhu Mythos](/wiki/Cthulhu_Mythos "Cthulhu Mythos"), such as Keziah Mason from the 1933 [H.P. Lovecraft](/wiki/H.P._Lovecraft "H.P. Lovecraft") short story "The Dreams in the Witch House", who is depicted as a servant of the alien ["Outer Gods"](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outer_Gods "wikipedia:Outer Gods"). Keziah Mason was an old woman who lived in a house in Arkham during the 1692 Salem witch trials, and was one of the many accused witches arrested - in her testimony to the judge, Keziah spoke of "lines and curves that could be made to point out directions leading through the walls of space to other spaces beyond", as well as describing a pitch-black man later revealed to be an avatar of Nyarlathotep. Keziah later disappeared mysteriously from Salem Gaol, leaving behind "curves and angles smeared on the grey stone walls with some red, sticky fluid" that were inexplicable even to the most studied clergymen of the time. Protagonist Walter Gilman, who moved into her former home, begins having bizarre dreams where he falls under Keziah's influence.

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Witch (dNetHack)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
@ witch (No tile)
Difficulty 13
Attacks Weapon 1d6 physical, Magic 1d6 clerical spell
@ witch (No tile)
Difficulty 13
Attacks

Weapon 1d6 physical, Magic 1d6 clerical spell

Base level 10
Base experience 266
Speed 12
Base AC 6
Base MR 45
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 400
Size medium

A witch:

  • can fly.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is a human.
  • is female.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can pick up magical items.
  • can be seen through infravision.

A witch, @, is a type of monster that appears in dNetHack and notdNetHack. The witch is a strong human woman that is capable of flight and spellcasting, can be seen via infravision and will seek out and collect items, particularly magical items.

A witch has a single weapon attack, and will attempt to cast spells clerically once during each of her turns: she can cast psi bolt, acid rain, evil eye, and curse items with an equal probability of each. A witch can only cast spells if her familiar is present, but is able to do so without any cooldown, and will summon another familiar if hers is killed.

Generation

Witches are not randomly generated, and are not a valid form for polymorph. An apprentice witch can grow up into a regular witch.

At level creation, three witches are generated accompanying their apprentices and the coven leader in the Temples of the Old Gods within the Neutral Quest. A witch's familiar is generated alongside each witch, at the same level as her.

A witch is always generated with black high boots, a plain dress, a black cloak, a black pair of gloves, a witch hat, and either a stiletto (9⁄10 chance) or an athame (1⁄10 chance).

Strategy

Witches are likely to be quite an annoyance on their own, even without their familiars' open wounds spells all but forcing you to avoid line-of-sight when approaching the witch coven. Though a familiar's casting abilities and importance to her witch should make the them a priority target in theory, only the witches are capable of flying - in practice, this results in them leaving the familiars behind to cast at you from across the river. Dealing with the witch battalion generally requires that characters have a high amount of HP and a source of half spell damage.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Witchcraft
Wikipedia has an article about:
The Dreams in the Witch House

Witchcraft refers to the alleged use of supernatural or magic powers primarily to inflict harm and misfortune upon others, with practitioners of the art known as "witches". European belief in witchcraft traces back to classical antiquity, with medieval and early modern European cultures playing host to witch hunting: the accused "witches" were usually women believed to have used black magic or maleficium against their own community, with the accusations borne of social tensions and believed by some anthropologists to have been focused on supposed enemies of the Church. Witchcraft is also generally considered malevolent in many indigenous belief systems, with people seeking healers and medicine people for protection against witchcraft. Believed to be driven by evil spirits or substances, suspected historical witches were intimidated, banished, attacked or outright killed - often they would be formally prosecuted and punished if they considered or simply believed to be guilty, resulting in tens of thousands of executions.

Witchcraft in its modern context generally refers to followers of certain types of modern paganism, who self-identify as witches and use the term witchcraft for their beliefs and practices, though some other neo-pagans avoid the term due to its negative connotations. Witches are also depicted in various forms of media as practitioners of magic that can range from empowered humans to almighty sorcerers to monstrous hag-like beings, and there are many instances of a witch "species" separate from mundane humanity. Witches in fairy tales and cartoons, particularly of the "monster" variety, are often depicted as long-nosed crones that are malevolent and seen as hideous witch croaky voices and shrieking laughs - they often wear distinct pointed brimmed hats and are sometimes depicted taking flight, with the stereotypical witch using a broom; many of these qualities are sometimes omitted or even subverted in modern depictions.

The witches of dNetHack are mostly based on cultists from the Cthulhu Mythos, such as Keziah Mason from the 1933 H.P. Lovecraft short story "The Dreams in the Witch House", who is depicted as a servant of the alien "Outer Gods". Keziah Mason was an old woman who lived in a house in Arkham during the 1692 Salem witch trials, and was one of the many accused witches arrested - in her testimony to the judge, Keziah spoke of "lines and curves that could be made to point out directions leading through the walls of space to other spaces beyond", as well as describing a pitch-black man later revealed to be an avatar of Nyarlathotep. Keziah later disappeared mysteriously from Salem Gaol, leaving behind "curves and angles smeared on the grey stone walls with some red, sticky fluid" that were inexplicable even to the most studied clergymen of the time. Protagonist Walter Gilman, who moved into her former home, begins having bizarre dreams where he falls under Keziah's influence.

A '''witch''', {{black|@}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]]. The witch is a [[strong]] [[Human (monster attribute)|human]] woman that is capable of [[flight]] and [[dNetHack monster spells|spellcasting]], can be seen via [[infravision]] and will seek out and collect items, particularly [[magical item]]s.

A witch has a single weapon attack, and will attempt to cast spells clerically once during each of her turns: she can cast [[psi bolt]], [[acid rain]], [[Evil eye (monster spell)|evil eye]], and [[curse items]] with an equal probability of each. A witch can only cast spells if [[Witch's familiar|her familiar]] is present, but is able to do so without any cooldown, and will summon another familiar if hers is killed.

==Generation==
Witches are not randomly generated, and are not a valid form for polymorph. An [[apprentice witch]] can grow up into a regular witch.

At level creation, three witches are generated accompanying their apprentices and the coven leader in the Temples of the Old Gods within the [[Neutral Quest (dNetHack)|Neutral Quest]]. A witch's familiar is generated alongside each witch, at the same level as her.

A witch is [[Monster starting inventory|always generated with]] black [[high boots]], a [[plain dress]], a black [[Plain cloak|cloak]], a black [[pair of gloves]], a [[witch hat]], and either a [[stiletto]] ({{frac|9|10}} chance) or an [[athame]] ({{frac|10}} chance).

==Strategy==
Witches are likely to be quite an annoyance on their own, even without their familiars' [[open wounds]] spells all but forcing you to avoid line-of-sight when approaching the witch coven. Though a familiar's casting abilities and importance to her witch should make the them a priority target in theory, only the witches are capable of flying - in practice, this results in them leaving the familiars behind to cast at you from across the river. Dealing with the witch battalion generally requires that characters have a high amount of HP and a source of [[half spell damage]].
